title: 112_hr6459
content:
The "Investment Savings Access After Catastrophes Act of 2012" allows for the suspension of personal casualty loss limitations in Hurricane Isaac disaster areas in Louisiana and Mississippi. SEC. 3 suspends personal casualty loss limitations for losses in the Hurricane Isaac disaster area, while SEC. 4 addresses net operating losses related to Hurricane Isaac. During a 2-year period after August 26, 2012, taxpayers with a net operating loss from Hurricane Isaac can extend their carryback period to 5 years and suspend the 90% AMT limitation. This applies to losses in the Hurricane Isaac disaster area. The term "Hurricane Isaac loss" is defined as the lesser of the net operating loss for the taxable year minus the specified liability loss, or the deduction for qualified Hurricane Isaac casualty loss. Qualified Hurricane Isaac casualty loss refers to specific losses related to the hurricane. The term "qualified Hurricane Isaac casualty loss" refers to uncompensated section 1231 losses of property in the Hurricane Isaac disaster area, allowed as a deduction under section 165 of the tax code for the taxable year due to Hurricane Isaac. Applicable rules similar to section 1400N(k) apply. SEC. 5. TAX-FAVORED WITHDRAWALS FROM RETIREMENT PLANS. Qualified Hurricane Isaac distribution treated as qualified hurricane distribution for eligible retirement plans from August 26, 2012, to September 11, 2014, for individuals in Hurricane Isaac disaster area with economic loss. Applicable rules similar to section 1400Q(a) of the Internal Revenue Code apply.

SEC. 6. RESCISSION OF UNSPENT AND UNCOMMITTED FEDERAL FUNDS. SEC. 6. RESCISSION OF UNSPENT AND UNCOMMITTED FEDERAL FUNDS. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will rescind unobligated Federal funds equal to the reduction in Federal revenues caused by the Act within 60 days of enactment, except for funds of the Department of Defense or Veterans Affairs.
